title: 108_hr898
content: The Act may be cited as the "Lumbee Recognition Act". The Act of June 7, 1956 is amended to acknowledge the Lumbee Indians of North Carolina as descendants of coastal tribes, recognized by the State since 1885 and by Congress in 1956. The Lumbee Indians are seeking full Federal recognition as an Indian tribe to receive benefits, privileges, and immunities accorded to federally recognized tribes. The Lumbee Indians are seeking full Federal recognition as an Indian tribe to receive benefits, privileges, and immunities accorded to federally recognized tribes. SEC. 3. FEDERAL RECOGNITION. The Act of June 7, 1956 is amended to extend Federal recognition to the Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina, allowing them to receive benefits and services provided to Indians. Indians in Robeson and adjoining counties not enrolled in the Lumbee Tribe may petition for tribal acknowledgement. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina, upon verification of a tribal roll, will be eligible for services and benefits provided to Indians. Members residing in specific counties will be considered as residing on or near an Indian reservation. The Secretaries of the Interior and Health and Human Services will develop a budget for these services in consultation with the tribe. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina's tribal roll will define the service population for federal services, subject to verification by the Secretary of the Interior. Fee lands for trust conveyance will be treated as on-reservation acquisitions if located in Robeson County. North Carolina will exercise jurisdiction over certain areas. The State of North Carolina will have jurisdiction over criminal offenses and civil actions on lands owned by the Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina. The Secretary of the Interior can accept jurisdiction transfer from the state to the United States after consulting with the Attorney General. The jurisdiction transfer may not take effect until 2 years after the agreement. This subsection does not impact the Indian Child Welfare Act. Appropriations are authorized to carry out this Act.
